	<item>
		<title>Shared Kitchen - Corridor Rules</title>
		<link>http://blog.andreineculau.com/2009/09/shared-kitchen-corridor-rules/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 25 Sep 2009 19:34:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.andreineculau.com/?p=854</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Starting this spring, I've moved to a shared kitchen SSSB corridor.

Quite many pluses, but one big minus that sometimes tends to be highlighted and highlighted, over and over again: kitchen cleanliness.

Reasons for complaining, one can find whenever.  I am one of them. I'm not hiding it. But what could differentiate me from others is that I try to see a way to fight it, and not a way to run from the complaints. Whether I managed to win over it or not, others need to judge.

That being said, usually there are two options that people see: <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forrest_gump">run, Forrest, run</a>! People are afraid of talking, of confrontations, some lack the communication skills to diffuse a situation, some lack the skills to see the middle way, etc. And then you have those that do not care at all.. or the ones (Swedes) that care, but they are shit-scared of confrontations - most probably since they are used to situations when the "guilty" person notices the mistake and says "Sorry! I'll fix it!" first..

Personally, I have a tendency to be harsh - my way or the high way. Most of the times I'm keeping focused on the situation, and not on the people. So if I say "Please clean!", once you do clean your mess, the ground for a possible good relationship arises instantaneously. But it's hard to see that, I know.

Enough said! My advice consist of the following:<!--more-->
<ul>
	<li><strong>Take the lead!</strong> If you don't do anything about your unhappy corridor, then do not expect somebody else to do it for you.</li>
	<li><strong>Have a meeting at the beginning of each semester</strong> with the whole corridor people - put up a note with possible dates and times, and let people decide during a week when to do it, and then put another note saying exactly when you'll have the meeting
<ul>
	<li><strong>Start by introducing yourself to everyone else</strong>, and then let everyone else do the same. It's good to know people's background since that might lead to knowing their expectations, and also you will know what their interests are so that next time you know how to connect to them.</li>
	<li><strong>Set a common corridor fee for common expenditures.</strong> We have 50 SEK per semester from each person in order to buy cleaning tools, lightbulbs, etc.</li>
	<li><strong>Ask for a special fee</strong>, if there's a common need for a one-time purchase like a microwave oven.</li>
	<li><strong>Talk!</strong> Not everybody is evil as you think. People do mistakes, have different routines and standards and might not see their mistakes, but they might be willing to do something about them. *Note to self, as well*</li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li>SSSB usually separates duties between corridor and kitchen. I decided to go by logic: <strong>somebody cleans the kitchen, and somebody else cleans the corridor and the kitchen floor</strong>. This has to happen at the end of the week, but it's good to have  a time range. Not everyone is  has the time or will to do is specifically on Sunday evening, and it's not a job. It's a duty in order to comply with SSSB rules and with common-sense sharing common laws.</li>
	<li><strong>Put corridor rules in all visible places</strong>.</li>
	<li><strong>Put small notes to remind people about specific duties.</strong></li>
	<li><strong>Encourage people to clean by themselves</strong> now and then, for others but most importantly for themselves - the cleaning responsible needs to assure that the place is disinfected, but he/she is not supposed to scrub 2 hours other people's mess.</li>
	<li><strong>Whenever things go wrong</strong>, take a post-it note, write something and put it on a door or a kitchen cabinet. No need to sign if it's a common sense request. If you get mad and get violent with doors, or whatever, the person that is the cause of this might never get you. And if you lack or doubt your social and communication skills that are appropriate for other cultures, then writing is the same way. Remember to put "please!". Magical word!</li>
	<li><strong>Have an end-of-the-week checklist</strong>, so that people can write their complaints in the easiest manner ever. Put a small pencil near.</li>
</ul>
Here are the documents that I have created for my corridor: <a href="http://files.andreineculau.com/projects/civic/SSSB_Corridor+rules.docx">corridor rules and notes</a>, <a href="http://files.andreineculau.com/projects/civic/SSSB_END+OF+THE+WEEK+checklist.docx">checklist</a>. Welcome to share or modify!

Hope this helps some other people too :) My corridor.. it might be my impression but it's way way better than how it used to be. Might not be perfect, but remember that no human being is perfect.

PostScriptum: the biggest plus is that you are not isolating yourself. You meet different cultures, you end up trying some new food, you get to hear about events the normal way - from a person you know, and not from a damned online social community to which you RSVP.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:post_name>shared-kitchen-corridor-rules</wp:post_name>

	<item>
		<title>(we&#039;ll be) Bringing common sense into unis&#039; IT life</title>
		<link>http://blog.andreineculau.com/2009/09/well-be-bringing-common-sense-into-unis-it-life/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 29 Sep 2009 09:10:12 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.andreineculau.com/?p=856</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[2nd semester of Engineering and Management of Information Systems programme  at KTH (Stockholm, Sweden) has a compulsory course entitled Project Management for Information Systems. "So what?" you'll say.

So, our (Miga, Gaia, Aron and I) engagement will be not to fake a project and its management, but to have a tangible and valuable IT product to manage and to develop.

In short, we will be doing a project of IT system integration with interaction features, developed for the mobile phone - it will make use of a social bookmarking browser called <a href="http://www.squace.com">Squace</a>. The integration part will cover notifying students of academic events (timetable), messages in academic email inboxes and forums (limited to their uni), articles from academic RSS feeds, etc. among others. The interaction part gives students the ability to comment informally on events, courses, people, public messages. The reasoning behind this approach is very simple. A recent counting, lead me to these results concerning KTH/DSV students: 5 Email addresses, 6+ services that can have different passwords, 20+ web addresses that they should access, they are expected to work with 4 management systems) ! I rest my case.

As for the mobile implementation, that is due to a closely working with Squace in the near future to come and because.. let's face it.. how many times did you end at school not knowing in which classroom you're having your next lecture? Do you really want to open up your laptop just to check a classroom?

We will try to develop this project with as many interfaces/APIs needed in order to make integration with other universities' systems as easy as possible. We see a real value in this project for many students, not just KTH/DSV students.

The deadline for this project is the very very early beggining of December 2009. Let's see what we make of these next two months :)

If you want to go in detail, you can read <a href="http://files.andreineculau.com/education/kth/2.1/PM-IV2401_-_Business_Case.pdf">our business case</a> and to check <a href="http://files.andreineculau.com/education/kth/2.1/PM-IV2401_-_Business_Case_Supporting_Files.zip">the supporting files</a> (Gantt, work breakdown, costs, risks, etc).
If you want to follow the progress of this project, you can subscribe to <a href="http://blog.andreineculau.com/tag/iv2401/feed/">the RSS feed of this project's tag on my blog</a>.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Clover :)</title>
		<link>http://blog.andreineculau.com/2009/10/clover/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 14 Oct 2009 22:30:21 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.andreineculau.com/?p=859</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[A small update on the <a href="http://blog.andreineculau.com/2009/09/well-be-bringing-common-sense-into-unis-it-life/">project</a> to integrate academic information systems and bring them to your student mobile, and create a community around it.

For starters, apparently Gaia came with <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clover">Clover</a> as a name (a <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Four-leaf_clover">four-leaf clover</a> since the team is made up by 4 people, and since that is a symbol of good luck), and that was in line with my thought to name it after a flower, since the previous project developed by KTH students for KTH (a project that is being used even today) is called Daisy :) The roots of that, we don't know. At first, we thought that we will each come up with a name, and then during one week we will use that as a reference to our project and see if it sticks, but.. I guess Clover works just fine since there was no other proposal :) [this is not the project leader speaking, because this might seem like a decision, but actually we didn't take the final decision to name it Clover]

Secondly, I would like to have a "<strong>in your face!</strong>" update :) and let all those doubting the mere data extraction from our DSV systems that... we are now already able to extract courses, events and messages, properly I might add, from 4 systems: Daisy, kth.se, TimeEdit and FirstClass. Coming up next will be extracting people (Daisy), registered courses (Daisy, Ladok) and academic emails. So I can already tell you that the basic functionality of integrating systems seems very feasible, and not ambitious :D [to give you a timeline, we have yet another two weeks to put the data extraction together]

PS: a small bonus update is that the data extraction process can extract messages from all sub-conferences (all sub-levels) of a conference :) people taking the "Project Management of IT Systems" know what I'm hinting at :p]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>2010 = 2009 = 2008 = ... for studera.nu</title>
		<link>http://blog.andreineculau.com/2010/01/2010-2009-2008-for-studera-nu/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 27 Jan 2010 16:10:34 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.andreineculau.com/?p=862</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Yesterday I received a message from one of this year's applicants tfo higher studies in Sweden. I will not say more. It speaks for itself. Sad. Very sad.
*Information in square-brackets is a substitute to original titles, on the applicant's request.
<blockquote>Hello Andrei:

I came across your studera.nu wikipage and I just wanted to thank you  for the information. Actually, I wish I'd found it much earlier as I  definitely would have made many changes to my application this year.

Your page has validated a lot of what I thought about the entire  Swedish university application process! I found it to be very cryptic  and never forthcoming about any of the requirements. It's not just studera.nu that's not  clear: I contacted several people at [a prestigious Stockholm university] (where I've applied) and they  each said something slightly different about what I should include in my  application and letter of intent. At times, they contradicted each  other and the information on studera.nu.  And when I sent a message through studera, I waited several days to  receive a generic, cut-and-pasted response of info already available on  the website.. they didn't address my specific question or the fact that I  was confused!

What is most frustrating is that I know I'm a great candidate for  the programme I want to pursue in terms of my grades, employment  experience, research projects and papers, volunteer/extracurricular  activities, etc. I thought very carefully before applying and chose just  one programme where I'm best suited and that best suits me. YET, I'm  almost certain now that I won't even be considered since I don't think  all my documents will reach the Higher Education Offices on time. For  one, I went to school in North America so my transcript must be sent  directly by my university -- although I requested this weeks ago, my  school uses an obscure courier service with no service guarantees, and  it looks like my transcript still hasn't arrived. And though I initially  thought the PO Box address on the studera.nu page looked strange, I assumed it would  be ok as I'm not too familiar with Swedish addresses, and I sent my  documents there. [World-class express courier] gave me a guarantee that they'd arrive this week,  but I'm starting to doubt it based on what I've read on your page about  Stroemsund's remoteness. Why would they NOT mention the contact person  and street address for mail via courier? Why would applicants have to  get this info on their own?? And why is there no phone number to call  and ask questions directly? It makes no sense at all.

By the way, is it true that it may take weeks before the status of  my documents on the studera website changes to say that the documents  have arrived? So is there no way of knowing if they've arrived by the  Feb 1, 2010 deadline?

This program would have been perfect for me, and I was so excited  about studying at [a prestigious Stockholm university], but now I've decided to (almost) forget about the  whole thing and not to get my hopes up. Everything I've read so far is  indicating my application likely won't even reach Stroemsund, never mind  actually going through the selection process.

Anyway, it is a bittersweet relief to know I'm not the only one who  expected so much more from the application process to some of the top  universities in the world. Thanks again for your webpage and the  invaluable information. (I'm so frustrated and a little disgusted with  the process, I probably won't bother reapplying next year)

Regards and best wishes with your studies.
<span style="color: #888888;">M</span>﻿</blockquote>]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2010-01-30 13:34:21</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Every foreign applicant to Sweden has gone through what you are. I bet things will work out. YES it takes some time for the statuses to be updated and YES you end up checking your f'n studera account 3x every day, even more sometimes, to see if there's new information. And YES once you get the final decision your life feels a little empty because you don't have the check the stupid website anymore. 

Please remember, even if you get negative news in the coming weeks, especially if it is about documents not arriving, do not take ANYTHING as even close to final until a few weeks before the decision deadline. Even then, a friend of mine didn't agree with the decision to not allow him in his program, so he called the program coordinator to ask why he was rejected. The coordinator realized he was a good candidate and changed his status to let him in. So don't give up. 

As far as the contradicting and difficult to track down information, if you want to come to Sweden get used to it. It doesn't stop at the university. Banks, any government office, etc, all will give you different stories depending on who you talk to, the time of day, how close the moon is to the earth, etc.]]></wp:comment_content>

	<item>
		<title>Shrink policy</title>
		<link>http://blog.andreineculau.com/2010/02/shrink-policy/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 05 Feb 2010 14:08:58 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.andreineculau.com/?p=864</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[A few weeks ago, a friend of mine had the reply "I'm not everybody's shrink. They were barking at the wrong tree.." (referring to the fact that he doesn't have to hear about everybody's problems)

A few days ago, <a href="http://trendsupdates.com/engadget-turns-off-comments-to-blog-posts-on-account-of-anonymous-inflammatory-comments/">Engadget closed down their comments</a>.

A few hours ago, I read "<a href="http://www.fuelyourblogging.com/conversation-is-essential-listening-is-optional/">Conversation is essential. Listening is optional</a>".

A few minutes ago, I was thinking about paying for the right to comment, to be heard, to express yourself in a certain environment. Kind of a shrink policy - you pay, I listen.

Information got very much quantitative, but how much/less qualitative?

Until then, maybe there are ways to ease down with tweaks like <a href="http://lifehacker.com/5464339/shutupcss-silences-web-site-comments">shutUp</a>.

PS: funny how now some of us put a lot of energy into running away from being <a href="http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/digitalnation/view/">distracted</a> by <a href="http://www.news.com.au/technology/multitaskers-distracted-by-everything-stanford-study/story-e6frfro0-1225766216881">everything</a>.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>864</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-02-05 15:08:58</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2010-02-05 14:08:58</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>shrink-policy</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>

	<item>
		<title>On the tuition fees for Swedish Higher Education</title>
		<link>http://blog.andreineculau.com/2010/07/on-the-tuition-fees-for-swedish-higher-education/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 08 Jul 2010 21:30:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.andreineculau.com/?p=866</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://blog.andreineculau.com/2008/06/free-swedish-tuition-at-its-end/">The rumors</a> have come reality. Free Swedish tuition came to its end.

The latest development puts Lund and Uppsala universities with tuition fees ranging from 80.000 to 180.000 SEK/year starting 2011 for non-EU/EEA students. <a href="http://www.lu.se/o.o.i.s?id=15111&amp;news_item=5343">source1</a>, <a href="http://www.uu.se/nyheter/nyhet.php?typ=artikel&amp;id=1064">source2</a>

The following is a reply to <a href="https://fromoventofreezer.wordpress.com/2010/07/08/the-new-costs-of-studying-in-sweden/">a blog post</a> against the tuition fees:
<blockquote>Daniela,
I read your post, and having been in touch with the admission to Swedish  HE, I can say this:

1. Fees are only for non-EU, since EU citizens are supposed to  treated as equals to Swedes. Thus, if the fees were to apply to EU  people as well, the same fees would apply to Swedes, and the Swedish  state is still in favor of free education (at least for its nation).<!--more-->

2. Unfortunately I do not have the right numbers for “cost per  student in Sweden” i.e. how much does the Swedish state spend for the  education of one student per year, but you can check how the situation  is in the US <a rel="nofollow" href="http://www.epodunk.com/top10/per_pupil/">http://www.epodunk.com/top10/per_pupil/</a>
Say on avg. 7000$/student/year, say roughly 50000 SEK/student/year in  Sweden. A regular non-EU student that comes is supposed to have 70000  SEK in a bank account per year. Many (I won’t mention nationalities) do  not spend that money each month. They have their ways around, legal or  illegal, and sometimes disturbing the others that expect a normal and  civilized life in Sweden. But even if you spend 70000 SEK every year,  how much do you think turns back to the Swedish state through taxes?!
Surely not enough as to “gain” from foreign students..

3. Swedish institutions had in their sight to have as many students  as possible, since they received money from the state for each student  they have. Thus do not believe for a second that they would deny  low-educated students. As long as there are enough places (stretching  them to the maximum possible), s/he will get admitted. And this  happened, while the quality of education would only get lower – 1  professor to 10 students is beyond doubt of better quality than 1  professor to 50 students. And the quality of the students is distributed  more or less the same, I would say, if you do not consider  scholarships. If you do consider them, you will surely have a better  ratio good vs less-good students.

I, for one, understand very well your situation, as I was non-EU a  few years ago. But I do have to say, after living in Sweden, that the  measure is a necessity. Both for the Swedish nation, and for the good  students that want a high quality education.

Last, but not least, I would like to put a rhetoric question – as a  student that I am interested in my education, since it affects directly  my own character and my own professional future, how could I be on the  same side with students that argue that they will choose other countries  that have tuition fees BUT have better weather, or less of a language  barrier (9 in 10 Swedes speak more than good English), etc?
Or students that think that the Swedish economy will go down because of  fewer foreign students.

One needs to be insane to think that a state like Sweden is taking  such a foolish decision. Although I only perceive the surface of the  problem, I am still in tune with the Swedish state for engaging in  tuition fees. If I weren’t in tune, I would be careful when giving such a  strong negative message against this decision.</blockquote>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Nice Translator for Firefox (with Hotkey)</title>
		<link>http://blog.andreineculau.com/2010/08/nice-translator-for-firefox-with-hotkey/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 08 Aug 2010 14:59:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.andreineculau.com/?p=868</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The Nice Translator Firefox Extension is an adaptation of the original  <a href="http://nicetranslator.com/">Nice Translator website</a>.

It allows a user to translate into multiple  languages at a time, as they type right from within a website. Select  text and immediately have it translated with just a few clicks.

But there's a problem. Because it was designed for selected-text translation, the only way to access it is to right-click a page: no hotkey, no toolbar button.

Since it's a really good language tool, today, I've spent a few minutes to make this compatible with Firefox 3.* and add a hotkey to <a href="https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/11458/">the original Firefox extension (ver. 0.3)</a> - Ctrl+Q.

<a href="http://files.andreineculau.com/projects/firefox/nice_translator_w_hotkey.0.3.xpi">Click to download - Nice Translator (with Hotkey) 0.3</a>

PS: if you are not ok with this key combination, you can just
<ol>
	<li>download the .xpi (right click, Save as...)</li>
	<li>rename the .xpi file to .zip</li>
	<li>edit the file within named <em>chrome/content/ntff.js</em> and change line 114 to suite  your needs</li>
	<li>rename back to .xpi</li>
	<li>drag-and-drop the changed file on Firefox</li>
</ol>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>868</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-08-08 15:59:28</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2010-08-08 14:59:28</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>nice-translator-for-firefox-with-hotkey</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Trac on Dreamhost</title>
		<link>http://blog.andreineculau.com/2010/11/trac-on-dreamhost/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 10 Nov 2010 17:33:16 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.andreineculau.com/?p=870</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Of course, you can read a lot about it on <a href="http://wiki.dreamhost.com/Trac">http://wiki.dreamhost.com/Trac</a>

<a href="http://trac.edgewall.org/">Trac</a>, the open-source project management and bug-tracking system, is now a one-click install on <a href="http://www.dreamhost.com">Dreamhost</a>, after a big struggle with installation scripts.

What you cannot read on the wiki, is this:
<ul>
	<li>change the date &amp; time format by doing the following
<ul>
	<li>look into your.trac.domain.com folder for index.fcgi</li>
	<li>edit the file, and add LC_TIME="sv_SE";export LC_TIME after the first line</li>
	<li>sv_SE is the locale identifier - you can see what locales you have available (Dreamhost has quite many) by typing "locale -a" in your SSH terminal</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<!--more-->
<ul>
	<li>change from sqlite (file) database to MySQL by doing the following
<ul>
	<li>create [your-trac-schema] in your <a href="http://panel.dreamhost.com">Dreamhost panel</a></li>
	<li>look into [your.trac.domain.com]/conf folder for trac.ini</li>
	<li>edit the file and look for database=sqlite:db/trac.db and change it to database=mysql://[username]:[password]@[your.domain.com]/[your-trac-schema]</li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li>use the same users and passwords that allow access to your linked SVN, by doing the following
<ul>
	<li>look into [your.trac.domain.com] folder for .htaccess</li>
	<li>edit it, and prepend these lines
<ul>
	<li>AuthType Basic
AuthName "Trac"
AuthUserFile /home/[your-username]/svn/[your-svn-project].passwd
Require valid-user</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
* items between [] need to be changed with your information]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>870</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-11-10 18:33:16</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2010-11-10 17:33:16</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>trac-on-dreamhost</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

	<item>
		<title>Pidgin and MSN (certificate error for omega.contacts.msn.com)</title>
		<link>http://blog.andreineculau.com/2010/11/pidgin-and-msn-certificate-error-for-omega-contacts-msn-com/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 18 Nov 2010 10:24:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.andreineculau.com/?p=872</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>UPDATE 2010-11-21 (the final solution for me)</strong>
<ol>
	<li>Download these two files: <a href="http://developer.pidgin.im/viewmtn/revision/downloadfile/cd236baf6d00f3e1561a40974ce1828b793ea187/share/ca-certs/Microsoft_Secure_Server_Authority_2010.pem">PEM#1</a> and <a href="http://developer.pidgin.im/viewmtn/revision/downloadfile/cd236baf6d00f3e1561a40974ce1828b793ea187/share/ca-certs/Microsoft_Internet_Authority_2010.pem">PEM#2</a> (part of UPDATE 2010-11-19 #2),
and rename them to
"Microsoft_Secure_Server_Authority_2010.pem" and
"Microsoft_Internet_Authority_2010.pem"</li>
	<li>Copy the above to files to "C:\Program Files\Pidgin\ca-certs" on Windows,
or "/usr/share/purple/ca-certs/" on Linux
NB! folder location may vary</li>
	<li><a href="http://files.andreineculau.com/projects/pidgin/omega.contacts.msn.com.2.txt">Download another file</a> (part of UPDATE 2010-11-19 #1)
and rename it to
"omega.contacts.msn.com"</li>
	<li>Copy the last file to "%APPDATA%\.purple" on Windows
or "~/.purple" on Linux
NB! folder location may vary</li>
	<li>Now re-enable your MSN account, or just quit and restart Pidgin altogether.</li>
</ol>
<strong>UPDATE 2010-11-19 #2 (not tested personally, but it's the solution that has been <a href="http://developer.pidgin.im/viewmtn/revision/info/cd236baf6d00f3e1561a40974ce1828b793ea187">uploaded for Pidgin's next update</a>)</strong>
Download two certificate files (<a href="http://developer.pidgin.im/viewmtn/revision/downloadfile/cd236baf6d00f3e1561a40974ce1828b793ea187/share/ca-certs/Microsoft_Secure_Server_Authority_2010.pem">no1</a> and <a href="http://developer.pidgin.im/viewmtn/revision/downloadfile/cd236baf6d00f3e1561a40974ce1828b793ea187/share/ca-certs/Microsoft_Internet_Authority_2010.pem">no2</a>)  and copy them this time into your Pidgin installation folder, under  "ca-certs" (probably "C:\Program Files\Pidgin\ca-certs" on Windows, or  /usr/share/purple/ca-certs/ on Linux).

<strong>UPDATE 2010-11-19 #1
</strong>Seems like Microsoft changed the SSL certificate again... Or I don't  know, but the situation looks more like there's a different SSL  certificate depending on the connection?! I uploaded a second one that  people can try. At this moment, I use one certificate on one computer,  and the second certificate on another computer (another Internet  connection). You can thus try with <a href="http://files.andreineculau.com/projects/pidgin/omega.contacts.msn.com.2.txt">the 2nd certificate</a>.

---

This morning, people started to have problems with <a href="http://www.pidgin.im">Pidgin</a> and their MSN accounts.

Apparently, Microsoft changed something (i.e. SSL certificate) on their servers.
<ul>
	<li><strong><span style="text-decoration: line-through;"><a href="http://files.andreineculau.com/projects/pidgin/omega.contacts.msn.com.txt">Download this file (2010-11-18)</a> or </span>
</strong></li>
	<li><strong><a href="http://files.andreineculau.com/projects/pidgin/omega.contacts.msn.com.2.txt">Download this file (2010-11-19)</a></strong>,</li>
	<li><strong>delete the ".txt" extension (or ".2.txt")</strong>, so that you end up with <strong>"omega.contacts.msn.com" only</strong>,</li>
	<li><strong>copy the file</strong> to your "<strong>.purple/certificates/x509/tls_peers</strong>" folder (<a href="http://developer.pidgin.im/wiki/Using%20Pidgin#Whereismy.purpledirectory">which you can find like this on Windows</a> / which is in your home directory on Linux), <strong>replacing the old "omega.contacts.msn.com" file</strong>,</li>
	<li>and finally</li>
	<li><strong>Quit</strong> (from the menu: Buddies -&gt; Quit) and restart your Pidgin.</li>
</ul>
PS: to put minds at rest, the SSL certificate is taken from <a href="https://omega.contacts.msn.com">https://omega.contacts.msn.com</a> . If you have the knowledge, you can download it yourself there, and follow the rest of the steps.]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Another fix is to do the following:

1. Close Pidgin
2. Find your certificates folder (Windows: %appdata%\.purple) (Linux: /home/.purple)
3. Delete everything in the certificate folder.
4. Restart pidgin and eventually you should get a new certificate that works.

P.S: Windows users who aren't familar with %appdata% just type %appdata%\.purple in your address bar and press enter.]]></wp:comment_content>

			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2010-11-18 12:33:32</wp:comment_date_gmt>

			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Marga]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>marga@rivero.com.ar</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>190.245.100.11</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2010-11-18 14:34:42</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2010-11-18 13:34:42</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Sorry for reposting, I'm just going to make this a bit clearer.

The first thing is to remove the invalid certificate. This can be done from Tools-&gt;Certificates.

After that, you might try to just reconnect and it might get a valid certificate, and you are done.

In case you are not, if running on Linux, you can do:

echo QUIT | openssl s_client -connect omega.contacts.msn.com:443 | openssl x509 &gt; omega.contacts.msn.com

And copy that file to: ~/.purple/certificates/x509/tls_peers

On windows, you can still use the solution posted here in the blog.]]></wp:comment_content>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[For people curious: The Gui Way.

Use Google Chrome. Open https://omega.contacts.msn.com/ and click yellow icon on top left, click "certificate information", open "details" tab and click export. Then rename file to omega.contacts.msn.com and put it in certificate folder. 

yeah, it is a long way. just don't bother and use the file here.]]></wp:comment_content>

			<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>200.19.188.11</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2010-11-18 21:05:18</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2010-11-18 20:05:18</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Hello,

If the error persist after copy the file and you use linux, try this:

Copy the file again to "~/.purple/certificates/x509/tls_peers" and change file's attributes:

sudo chattr +i "~/.purple/certificates/x509/tls_peers/omega​.con​tacts​.msn.com"

This makes the file readonly and pidgin can't alter it.

Sorry my bad english.. heeh ;)

--
Tiago Sales]]></wp:comment_content>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[@<a href="#comment-1805" rel="nofollow">Janneke</a>:
In my fc13,after doing this it works perferct:
mv Microsoft_Internet_Authority_2010.pem Microsoft_Secure_Server_Authority_2010.pem omega.contacts.msn.com  ~/.purple/certificates/x509/tls_peers/

Notice:
If you find your ~/.purple/certificates/x509/tls_peers/ has two file named omega.contacts.msn.com.

Don't directly copy this word 
"omega.contacts.msn.com" from the article above.Because it contain some blank space symbols between some letters in the word refered in the step3 in solution.]]></wp:comment_content>

			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Tiago Sales]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>tiagosales.ti@gmail.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>200.19.188.11</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2010-11-19 13:42:15</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2010-11-19 12:42:15</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Try This...

Tiago Sales wrote:
Hello,

If the error per sist after copy the file and you use linux, try this:

Copy the file again to “~/.purple/certificates/x509/tls_peers” and change file’s attributes:

sudo chattr +i ~/.purple/certificates/x509/tls_peers/omega​.con​tacts​.msn.com

This makes the file read only and pid gin can’t alter it.]]></wp:comment_content>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Thanks, followed your instruction and got it to work.

Downloaded the file from the URL:
http://developer.pidgin.im/viewmtn/revision/downloadfile/cd236baf6d00f3e1561a40974ce1828b793ea187/share/ca-certs/Microsoft_Secure_Server_Authority_2010.pem

moved the downloaded file to /usr/share/purple/ca-certs/

Started pidgin again.

And then.. All izz well.. 

I didn't had to delete any file while doing this.]]></wp:comment_content>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Similar to what Alex wrote on 18 November: for Windows, put the omega.contacts.msn.com file in %APPDATA%\.purple\certificates\x509\tls_peers. There may already be an omega.contacts.msn.com file there, which you may want to rename for safety or archival purposes before replacing it.]]></wp:comment_content>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Since this keeps happening and I must fix it over and over, I wrote myself a simple shell script which I leave in the ~/.purple/certificates/x509/tls_peers directory, execute it, and fire Pidgin back up. It is as follows:

#!/bin/bash

/bin/rm omega.contacts.msn.com
/usr/bin/wget 'http://files.andreineculau.com/projects/pidgin/omega.contacts.msn.com.2.txt'
/bin/mv omega.contacts.msn.com.2.txt omega.contacts.msn.com]]></wp:comment_content>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Remote debugging with xdebug 2.1 and Zend Studio 8</title>
		<link>http://blog.andreineculau.com/2010/12/remote-debugging-with-xdebug-2-1-and-zend-studio-8/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 03 Dec 2010 07:55:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.andreineculau.com/?p=874</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>UPDATE 20110407</strong>: If Apache crashes randomly when you activate debugging, make sure you run Apache with administrator rights. If you have it as a process (not as a service), just start xampp-control.exe by right-clicking and choosing "Run as administrator", and restart the Apache process

I'll put down some things I learned on the matter, along the question: how do you make it work?? solution!

So, to start from the beginning:
<ul>
	<li><a href="http://www.zend.com/en/products/studio/downloads">Zend Debugger</a> does not work on the latest <a href="http://www.apachefriends.org/en/xampp.html">XAMPP</a> 1.7.3, because it uses <a href="http://php.net/downloads.php">PHP 5.3.1 VC6 Thread Safe</a></li>
	<li>Zend stopped producing the Zend Debugger for PHP thread safe versions, because along with Microsoft, they reached the conclusion that non-thread safe is the only way to go</li>
	<li>The easiest way to get Zend Debugger and a Web Server up and running would be to download Zend Server (there's a Community Edition as well - free)</li>
	<li>My problem was this: for some reason the Zend Server was slow, produced errors now and then.. leaving plenty of php-cgi.exe processes behind, and a slow or a broken option to restart the web server</li>
</ul>
So I wondered around and leaned towards <a href="http://www.xdebug.org">xdebug</a> as an option to have XAMPP back.<!--more-->

Installing xdebug in xampp is rather easy. Get the latest binary from<a href="http://www.xdebug.org/download.php"> xdebug.org</a> . With XAMPP 1.7.3 you will need the "<em>5.3 VC6 Non-thread safe (32bit)</em>" version. If you want to be sure, follow the instructions on <a href="http://www.xdebug.org/find-binary.php">this page</a>. Put the downloaded binary under <em>xampp/php/ext</em> .

Step 1. Add/uncomment the following in <em>xampp/php/php.ini</em> (extract from my <em>php.ini</em>)
<pre>[XDebug]
zend_extension=<em>xampp\php\ext\php_xdebug-2.1.0-5.3-vc6.dll</em>
xdebug.profiler_enable = 1
xdebug.profiler_enable_trigger = 1
xdebug.profiler_output_dir = "<em>xampp\tmp</em>"
xdebug.profiler_output_name = "xdebug_profile.%p"
xdebug.remote_autostart = 0
xdebug.remote_enable = 1
xdebug.remote_handler = "dbgp"
xdebug.remote_host = "127.0.0.1"
xdebug.remote_log = "<em>xampp\tmp\xdebug.log</em>"
xdebug.remote_mode = "req"
xdebug.remote_port = 9000</pre>
Online, you can find tutorials asking for a different port (i.e. 10000), yet I had problems making xdebug accessing that port. Also, if you have your web server on a different machine than the one you will debug one, change the <em>remote_host</em> variable to the debugger's IP address. This variable can only take on IP address (debugging can take place only from one machine).

Step 2. After restarting your XAMPP (from the XAMPP Control Panel), you should test your configuration. You can easily do that by going either accessing a phpinfo() script, or going to your XAMPP website (usually http://localhost ) and clicking on the left-side "phpinfo()" link. You should find the following, right after the first table: "This program makes use of the Zend Scripting Language Engine: Zend Engine v2.3.0, Copyright (c) 1998-2009 Zend Technologies <strong>with Xdebug v2.1.0, Copyright (c) 2002-2010, by Derick Rethans</strong>". If you see the xdebug reference, you're set to go.

Step 3. To test for connectivity, you will need <a href="https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/58688/">a Firefox extension</a> called <em>easy xdebug</em> (that triggers remote debugging; ) and <a href="http://code.google.com/p/xdebugclient/">xdc (xdebugclient)</a>. <strong>This test will only work if you debug and run the web server on the same machine.</strong> After installation, go into xdc and tell it to start listening from the menu. Now, whenever you click on the green icon (lower right of the Firefox window) and it turns into a red circle, then refresh the remote page, you should end up in xdc, ready to step into, step over, step out of your coding lines. When the green icon has no red circle, it should run without triggering xdc.

Step 4. Everything works? Next, Zend Studio to be set up. Click Windows -&gt; Preferences.
Now, select <strong>PHP &gt; Debug</strong> . Select <strong>XDebug</strong> under <em>PHP Debugger</em>, then click on <em>Configure...</em>, click <em>XDebug</em>, click <em>Configure</em> and change <em>Accept remote session (JIT)</em> to <strong>any</strong>.
Go back to <strong>PHP &gt; Debug</strong> . Click <em>PHP Executables...</em>, then <em>Add</em>, and fill in with the path to <strong>xampp/php/php-cgi.exe</strong> and <strong>xampp/php/php.ini</strong>, SAPI = <strong>CGI</strong> and Debugger = <strong>XDebug</strong>.
Go back to <strong>PHP &gt; Debug</strong> . Select your PHP Executable that you've just created.

Now, if I didn't forget anything, it should all work i.e. When the green icon in Firefox has the red circle (= you request the page to be debugged), ZendStudio should start debugging. Some mention that you get a popup window asking you to do some path mapping (where you associate the script path on your remote machine with the script path on your debugging machine, or with a ZendStudio project path), but I don't get that (maybe because localhost is my debugging machine and my web server; it used to happen with Zend Debugger, but not with XDebug).

PS: This blog post is based on many online references, like <a href="http://bogdan-albei.blogspot.com/2010/06/php-remote-debugging-with-xdebug-and.html">this</a>, or <a href="http://devzone.zend.com/article/2930">this</a> and many others.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>A developer&#039;s review of webligo&#039;s SocialEngine</title>
		<link>http://blog.andreineculau.com/2011/01/an-developers-review-on-webligos-socialengine/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 19 Jan 2011 13:10:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.andreineculau.com/?p=875</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I will start with a humble <em>mea culpa</em> , making it clear that the following are my opinions (put together during some lunch breaks) and not a carefully written review. I'm doing this because there is actually no minimum review of this product.

I've started engaging with webligo's <a href="http://www.socialengine.net">SocialEngine</a> 2-3 months ago. SocialEngine is a social network framework that allows users to deploy a self-hosted social network, that wants to be easy to customize. The end goal of my job related to SocialEngine was to customize it according to some rather small requirements. This is what I can tell you after these months:

<strong>1. Context</strong> - It is important to state from the beginning why my team and I went ahead with SocialEngine. The frameworks that aid building a self-hosted social network are not many, apply some filters like +php +mysql +mvc -cms and you end up with one, if I'm not mistaken. There's <a href="http://buddypress.org">BuddyPress</a> (built on Wordpress) , and I-dont-recall-the-name built on Drupal, and many others but I said no to general CMS. There's also <a href="http://elgg.org">Elgg</a> , but when you end up looking at the source code (especially the code of plugins), you realize that the software is loose. <a href="http://www.joindiaspora.com">Diaspora</a> is promising, but it will be a long time before it comes out as a trustworthy platform. Today I read about <a href="http://www.anahitapolis.com/about/anahita-social-engine">Anahita</a>, but it is also a baby. Long story short, there is simply no good social network platform out there that keeps it simple with PHP&amp;MySQL support. Please tell me if I'm wrong.<!--more-->

<strong>2. Architecture</strong>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">2.1. SocialEngine is based on <a href="http://zendframework.com">Zend Framework</a>. Hurray! Except, if you read a few reviews online, Zend Framework is not a MVC platform, but more of a MVC helper if you will. It gives you too much freedom, not leading you (you=a ZF newbie).</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">2.2. SocialEngine uses MooTools for javascript. Hurray, some of you might say. Except, if you start coding with MooTools, after knowing the magic you can do with jQuery, you end up in a disgraceful situation. MooTools has its advantages, but overall, especially when you end up using some plugins.. Uff!</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">2.3. SocialEngine should use Smarty - ref <a href="http://www.socialengine.net/support/faq#faq38">http://www.socialengine.net/support/faq#faq38</a> yet it does NOT. Advantages and disadvantages occur. The negative part is that the templates being to look (not just visually) less of templates, and more like code.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">2.4. SocialEngine uses <a href="https://github.com/sunny/csscaffold">sunny's CSScafold</a> and again Hurray! This time it is a true hurray! Coding big apps without a CSS platform is pain in the.. But SocialEngine uses the platform just for some folder parsing and CSS include. So you end up loading a library for nothing.</p>
<strong>3. Documentation</strong> - none! They say that the code has comments, but I can tell you that that's not enough, and that the comments are sparse and sometimes are copied from other parts, with little connection to what lies below the comment.

<strong>4. Communication</strong>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">4.1 Support - they give you 30 days support when you purchase a license, yet they always put "we are overloaded, it can take a while for us to give feedback to your ticket". Furthermore, it's only support for errors. 2nd furthermore - there is no way to see other tickets and to leave comments.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">4.2. Censorship - you will now say that I don't know what I'm talking about, BUT please try to find one negative comment on their blog. I left a couple of comments, perfectly well-written and respectful, related to the blog posts, and the comments did not get approved. If you search online, there are quite many communities. It gives you a clear sense that this product is well known. Despite that, on each community you will see that people seek help for errors, plugins, etc. and almost no answer. My humble conclusion is that there are not many developers using SE, but just simple users that want to deploy their own social network.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">4.3. Blog posts importance - they will post and wish you a Happy New Year, but they will not post about a security issue. Instead they just mention (inside the <a href="http://www.socialengine.net/blog/article?id=119&amp;article=Happy-New-Year">Happy New Year post</a>) that the issue has been fixed (God knows how long ago that issue had been noticed).</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">4.4. Twitter - their twitter account is mostly dead, rarely answering mentions and rarely posting helpful things. You'd think that developers of a social network take communication seriously..</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">4.5. Email - my team and I wrote them at some point and asked them if they are willing to collaborate on strengthening the platform's code. There was no money or attribution involved, but we just wanted to make sure that future upgrades will not break our fixes. We knew early in our development cycle that we will notice&amp;kill security &amp; other issues, which did happen. No answer.</p>
<strong>5. Source code</strong>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">5.0 Legacy. This first bullet-point is not related to SocialEngine v4, but v3. Back in those times, all the code was in one big folder, and with little if any OOP in mind. Judge for yourselves.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">5.1. Think twice, speak once. One can see that there is a lot of human and intellectual resources being deployed into SocialEngine. No doubt about it. Work is work and should be appreciated for what it is. Yet it's another thing when you see code being copy-pasted instead of going with modular programming. That reflects both in PHP, HTML, CSS code and database structure. When does a good developer stop doing that in their evolution cycle?</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">5.2. CSS - each module has its own CSS, as if saying "don't touch, private property". Good, although it is fairly easy to override due to CSScafold's features. The template's CSS covers should cover non-modular styles. If you want to modify the CSS adequately and get out of their design box, you will spend a lot just to properly put the CSS code (one file per template, one file per module) in smaller files. Then even longer to eliminate redundant CSS code, which then leads to the need of eliminating redundant PHP code (e.g. widgets: Event's Profile Photos is the same with Group's Profile Photos).</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">5.3. One can clearly notice that SE developers do not have a sense of uniform coding practices. Compare the Controller.php from the Event's Profile Photos (or Discussion) with the one from the Group module. Even if they are doing the same thing, the newer one has more checks and filters (striptags, canPost, etc). One can also find comments like "does this work like this?", or "this could break if.."</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">5.4. I will stop here for now, and maybe update the post at a later time with source-code crap. Bottom line is that modules do not communicate properly with each other, and that after these 2-3 months, I am still "refurbishing".</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">5.5. Don't fix it if it ain't broken. I fully agree, but what do you do when you go ahead with a product, especially when building a community, and then you get in deep shit because of poorly written code, getting errors or bumping into security issues? Am I then supposed to say that it's not my fault, that I'm looking into it and not knowing how long it will take, etc? Communities are not that stable as one might think. They need to be nurtured, and a good way to start doing just that is provide a good home for them. Fixing a home before people come live in it is much easier than fixing it when people live there.</p>
<strong>Disclaimer</strong>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">My intent is not to trash the developers, nor the product, but to provide a singular opinion (or not, if other people concur with what I wrote) on this product and its team's practices from a developer point of view. It could be that if you are a simple customer, and you do not want to customize its core, then it is a very good product. In SocialEngine's defense, a simple and powerful argument for the product's strong position on the market is that I'm still going forward with it. The question is: for how long?</p>]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[I have to agree with your views on Social Engine.  At first it appeared that it would be a great for a site that my staff and I are developing.  But the lack of timely response to support tickets, the lack of adequate documentation for some of the common problems has caused our project to fall further and further behind.  It took the direct emails to Alex,BBB complaints and 2checkout and even more to get any type of reasonable response.  Sad to say, I'm at the point of not wanting to waste any more of my valuable time/resources and moving to a different solution. 

When other developers purchase your work and look forward to using it, it seems that you would do everything in your power to give them quality service.  I'd recommend taking notes from some of the wordpress developers, such as DIYthemes or CopyBlogger Media.  I'll admit their support and forums make purchasing their product worthwhile.  Just my thoughts. 

Thanks for writing this and motivating me enough to vent.]]></wp:comment_content>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[I am currently using SE4 to create a community. So far, it's be a pretty good experience.  My support at Webligo ran out and I re-upped.  I usually get responses and solution within 24 hours.

I am disappointed to see the issues people are having here.  I am not a hard-core coder but I get around ok.  I built my own widgets and currently working on a module.  

I can see how if you need to extend or alter SE4 extensively to fit an exact need then it might not be the best choice.  But I think for folks who find SE4's functionality fit 90% of their needs that this is a solid  product, and reasonably priced IMHO. 

Just my 2cents. Remember the grass is always greener on the other side.]]></wp:comment_content>

As for Kwolla (I think it's the first time I bump into it):
1. no screenshots = no transparency
2. no plugins, user base?
3. downloaded v1 to look through it, and, while the code looks pretty clean I must say, I find exactly the same idiocracy as in SE: the Photo module means Photo Albums, as the User module has support for photos. Make me doubt the whole thing

			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2011-02-15 12:25:40</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[UPDATE 3:

Zend Framework's route do not implement (to my knowledge) route priority. That is to say, once you add the routes in a queue, it takes them one by one in reverse and tries to match one with the URL.

Yet, when you work with sub-utems, the way you're supposed to do it in large projects, you need an option to sort the routes from specific/static to more general (e.g. module/controller/action). SocialEngine does NOT. Instead they charge money while they should give back money for poorly written code. To be exact: there's an "album" module that implements photo albums, and then there's an event and group module for instance, that implement photo uploading on their own. The same goes for the Discussion Boards, implemented at least twice, in Event and Group.

A programmer with the bare minimum skills and concern for ethics and sustainable code would never do that! Not unless money and time (deadlines) rule, not that this is a good excuse.]]></wp:comment_content>

			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2011-02-15 12:35:38</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[UPDATE 4:

I forgot to mention another crapy thing.

When you use a library, especially a well-written modular library like the Zend Framework, you simply do not touch the original code. NEVER! Instead, you just build on top of it, customizing piece by piece, even if you end up writing a bit more code. Why? Because when Zend Framework or any library updates itself, you just refresh your copy, and you move on unless major changes occured that break your code (although all respectable libraries are backward compatible up to some point).

Am I talking out of the blue? No. Example: SE4 modifies the Zend_Navigation_Page_Mvc's isActive function.

But maybe I'm wrong in my judgement.. who knows?]]></wp:comment_content>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Thank you very much for writing this article and for posting the updates. And if you don't mind I have a little story of my experience. (tl;dr at the end)

Late last year I had to work on SE4 with little knowledge of its architecture (Zend, its CSS techniques and MooTools). Coming from a...half-undergraduate understanding of CS, I thought I could just jump in and get a handle of things quickly. Of course that didn't turn out the way I expected. 

I ran into pretty much all your problems and every time I tried to look for help there was very little. Since I don't program in PHP often, I thought it was just me. I thought I just sucked at PHP and that the SE team and Zend are doing it right. Even after looking at so many var dumps (or print_r's) of single variables, I kept thinking to myself, "This is a HUGE object and A LOT of the values are duplicates. Is this really necessary?" and always assumed that it was.

After a while, I just gave up and started coding all my modifications quickly, and sloppily as I have no time to redo a lot of the code, as you are doing.

(tl;dr: Had trouble with Zend and SE, thought it was just me sucking at PHP. Article confirms that I don't suck (that much).)

So again, thanks for this article. I thought I was only one of the few who was getting frustrated with the entire platform.]]></wp:comment_content>

			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2011-03-02 09:16:09</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[UPDATE 5:

It's the simple thing that matter, they say.

While I'm trying to clean up the SE code, it's disgusting to see old/confused code like:

if (!$this->subject()->authorization()->isAllowed($this->viewer(), 'comment')) {return $this->_helper->requireAuth()->forward();}

instead of a regular

if (!$this->_helper->requireAuth(null, null, 'comment')->isValid()) return;

* not to mention that the helper can be made so much simpler

--

And then you have code that non only looks weird but is wrong:

if ($paginator->getTotalItemCount() < $paginator->count())

that is, compare the number of items with the number of pages?!

--

You also have navigation items that are hard-coded in different places or take from the database..

What a lack of uniformization and consistency...
And now I have to first understand the mess and re-structure ? How counter-productive is that!]]></wp:comment_content>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Thanks for your review Andrei. It will hopefully help a little to choose between these complex products. I guess most of the problem you identified are correct and should be looked at. Especially your concern over security makes me as a SE owner worried.

My mayor concern is also the way the SE Team is dealing with its developer-skilled or 'highend' customers. If they - and the SE clients with them - really want to make a difference on the internet with their SE, then this is essential. There is just no good connection going on, yet.

One of the positive things I experience is that SE and some of their externally developed Modules are very potential. The Modules of SE themselves are really crap. But for instance those of SocialEngineAddons really make a chance out there. Of course lots needs to be done, but still.

And to End my story. Everybody knows buying Se is like buying a budget airline ticket. You cannot go to the moon with this stuff. I actually have a 'travel-to-the-moon-ambition', but I will use the SE only for the startup phase, also during development it helps to just start developing a platform, because in my experience it is impossible to sketch it all on beforehand. And then SE comes useful if you do not have the money yet, or the time. Love to know what you think of this input ;D]]></wp:comment_content>

			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2011-01-27 15:18:04</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[UPDATE 1:
Their ENGINE ( app/libraries/engine ) library, which extends ZendFramework implements a FancyUpload form element.

This element redirects its decorator to a view under the STORAGE module ( app/modules/Storage/view/scripts/upload/upload.tpl).

In turn, this upload.tpl is coded to handle only ajaxed file uploading just for the ALBUM module.

Great work!

PS: Needless to say that the only thing that works is adding files/photos. Removing or clearing the whole list uses an URL that returns 404 not found]]></wp:comment_content>

			<wp:comment_author_IP>62.181.209.194</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2011-02-07 16:15:19</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2011-02-07 15:15:19</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[UPDATE 2:
SocialEngine uses SmoothBox for their modal popups.

First of all, it must be noted that SocialEngine uses MooTools 1.2 (1.3 released in October 2010, 4 months ago)

SmoothBox is port of ThickBox running on jQuery to MooTools.
Thickbox hasn't been developed since autumn 2009, and SmoothBox (from Boris Popoff)... since God knows when, but not very recently, as far as I can tell.

I beg to ask: why develop a brand new platform that uses libraries that seem on their way to extinction?

Furthermore, using JS libraries that do not have a minified version, nor place a minifying on-the-fly script for the core libraries?

Solution in place: moving slowly to jQuery and to ColorBox]]></wp:comment_content>

			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2011-01-21 07:41:48</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[@<a href="#comment-2135" rel="nofollow">Alex</a>: Thanks for your reply. My guess and my hope is that readers will make the right choice for themselves.]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
			<wp:comment_user_id>1</wp:comment_user_id>
		</wp:comment>
		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>2137</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Steve Davies]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>steve@fitchmedia.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>86.140.79.186</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2011-01-22 19:05:38</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2011-01-22 18:05:38</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Andrei, I concur with most of your points.  I ran a SE3 community before totally rebuilding it in SE4 - I'm not a simple user and have made significant changes to SE4, initially front-end design and layout, but then latterly in the model &amp; controller elements of modules.  I'm keeping most of my efforts focused on modules, so that I stand a chance of upgrading the core script with less impact.

Before SE4 was released I read up on ZF, but I've yet to find a 'similar' ZF installation so most (all) of the ZF documentation is of limited use.  I find CSScafold a real pain to work with, it renders Firebug nearly useless (you can't judge which CSS base file to alter), so I have spent a lot of my time trying to figure which line of CSS to adjust.  It could be in the module folder, or theme.css, or perhaps even main.css of the core module.  Then of course CSScafold adds an extra layer of caching that has left me pulling my hair out - I've resorted to deleting cache files directly from /temporary/scaffold at times.

Thankfully I learned early on about default.tpl and what it does, but ran into some problems with inheritance issues between this layout file and the admin layout editor – basically it’s designed to use a single default template, whereas I wanted several.  

I used Mootools on SE3 and got the hang of it, but use jQuery on all our other systems and there’s so much more that can be done – plus the range of new scripts that can be added or adapted.  I find myself adding jQuery scripts to SE4 whenever I need to (with the obligatory Noconflict declarations!). 

I’m currently trying to debug a problem with the Mootools modal script (Smoothbox) which only partially opens on my SE4 site, but am increasingly coming to the view that I’ll replace the whole modal setup with a jQuery script..

Like you I’ve assessed the other options on the market – I begin building our new community using Drupal OpenAtrium from the folks at Development Seed and whilst it’s a great script, it’s designed for intranets and I was undertaking too many modifications.  

Ultimately I will stick with SE4, it’s not presently designed for developers, but instead the newbie user who only wish to add a few modules, change some colours and leave it alone.  Once you start ‘really’ working with SE4, digging into its core, it’s a lonely place to exist – there’s little support, very little knowledge out there and a feeling of reinventing the wheel.  

I’ve made my views clear over on SE4.me, saying that SE needs to spread into the developer community and gain a proper support infrastructure then rather than require ‘simple users’ to install and configure their own SE4 installations, it would make much more sense to operate a hosted SaaS-like environment along the lines of wordpress.com, enabling these simple users to focus on building their communities rather than the endless “how do I change the colour of my header image” questions that seem to proliferate most SE forums.]]></wp:comment_content>

			<wp:comment_id>2135</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Alex]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>info@webligo.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url>http://www.socialengine.net</wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>71.140.200.203</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2011-01-19 23:58:06</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2011-01-19 22:58:06</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Andrei,

This is Alex from SocialEngine. I want to thank you for the honest review and reply to some of the negative points you've mentioned here.

1. We've seen some people feeling overwhelmed with the Zend Framework while others seem relieved or excited about it. Like any foundation/MVC, it offers a mixture of positives and negatives. On the negative side, it can be overwhelming and somewhat complicated. On the positive side, it's really quite flexible/extensible and comes with substantial documentation (which applies to SE). While it may not be perfectly suitable for everyone, we stand behind ZF as our choice of framework for SE4. Zend also offers various products/resources that are compatible with ZF for power users or enterprise - we think these offer SE some additional future potential.

2. I respectfully disagree that we are not utilizing CSS Scaffold properly. If you check out the theme files, you'll see that we are using it to set variables at the top of the theme, effectively creating a "theme config". While this perhaps doesn't use every feature of Scaffold, we think it's used in a simple, effective way. What we have seen is many, many more third-party theme/template designers building and selling SE4 themes than we did with SE3, so I think that's a very positive indication that the new system is an improvement.

3. Our support service has undergone some strain - this is due to very abrupt growth we've had since the initial SE4 release. However, we are actively hiring up and have recently *drastically* improved our support response time. We are dedicated to continue improving our quality of service.

4. You've mentioned the security issue found within our Music plugin recently. We actually released a patch for this several hours after it was reported. Our entire development team was assigned to the task - it was an absolute top priority. We have a very good track record in terms of security issues - only two issues have come up since the first SE4 release, and we've always released patches immediately. We also notified all our clients via email directly about the security issue and patch. The blog post was in no way designed to downplay the issue. Regardless, we'll make an effort to post any critical items like that in their own entries moving forward.

5. Unfortunately, when negative comments have been posted on our blog in the past, they are almost always irrelevant to the post itself, requests for support (in which case, we follow up directly), or problems stemming from customizations to the source code or third-party addons. In any case, we'll do our best to increase transparency wherever possible. We are also putting more man-hours into Twitter/Facebook - in the past this has meant taking time away from development (we still have a small team), but we are now training someone who will be communicating via these channels continuously.

6. Source code - SE4 was written from the ground up and is being continuously re-factored to improve uniformity. It was developed by a small team quite rapidly, so needless to say, there is room for improvement. We are sincerely committed to making it the best it can be.

Finally, I'm glad to hear that you're sticking with SE for your project. We look forward to seeing what you'll build.

Thanks!
Alex]]></wp:comment_content>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Facebook - what did I gain? Consumer vs producer</title>
		<link>http://blog.andreineculau.com/2011/06/facebook-what-did-i-gain-consumer-vs-producer/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 02 Jun 2011 13:08:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.andreineculau.com/?p=902</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Pre Scriptum: If you want to skip reading this post, <a href="http://www.geeksaresexy.net/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/socialmedia.jpg">click here and ponder about the message</a>. Or continue reading ;)
<blockquote>Hey Andrei,

You recently registered for Facebook using this email address.  To complete your registration, follow the link below:
http://www.facebook.com/c.php?...
(If clicking on the link doesn't work, try copying and pasting it into your browser.)

If you did not register for Facebook, please disregard this message.Check out http://www.facebook.com/help.php?page=49 if you have any questions.

Thanks,
The Facebook Team</blockquote>
<!--more-->This is the email I received on 2007-12-10. I guess I was bored and lonely in December :)

Anyways, I'm writing this post after reading that <a href="http://thenextweb.com/facebook/2011/05/31/report-96-of-americans-under-50-are-on-facebook/">more than 96% of Americans under 50 are on Facebook</a>. Moreover, you have 70% going there daily.

Immediately after I think: what did I gain? I did connect with some people and I appreciate that, although I ended up creating a list of ~20 people that I follow, and which also can see all of my shares. The rest of the "friends", are just contacts really. Ready to be imported and slow down my Android. My TweetDeck is already not showing my Facebook feed, just Facebook notifications.

I started to move more and more to Twitter, as an online newspaper, rather than sticking to the social newspaper (i.e. Facebook). And even there I started to create lists, and limit what I follow.

(Small clarification. As of now, given my usage, I look at Facebook and LinkedIn as social networks, although I contest the benefits of Facebook even in this category, and Twitter as a social media channel. Wrong perspective? Amateur perspective?)

In the past, media didn't cover so much (obvious reasons). Today it covers ~everything. Should I follow everything? If you think it's possible, just take a look at the numbers <a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Yk_Qkz_5ti8">http://www.slideshare.net/mzkagan/what-the-fk-is-social-media-one-year-later</a>

We moved away from newspapers and magazines to online media, and then to social media, for what exactly? Or why? I'm guessing it's an acknowledgement issue, as well as a speed+quality issue. Online media is indeed faster, and offline media maybe, but often isn't up to the readers' "standards". But moreover, I guess it's the lack of the ability to acknowledge that we do need "journalists". We do need people to filter out in the best way possible the noise from what is or could be important, from what could make a difference in the future. If we ignore those filters, we'll just become consumers. Consumers of other people's thoughts, people that actually have the ability to follow just 10 (random number) social media accounts.

Producing real goods, rather than just thoughts, should be encouraged. Instead "we" (don't blame it on "them"!) encourage people to follow other people, and tweet and re-tweet. 140 characters, links, photos. Multi-task (i.e. pretend that you do "stuff") is the new common sense, rather than take a small thought, transform it in an idea, see what are the possibilities of realizing that idea, gather others around it, implement it, move on. Many of us will die having "@user had 1 billion followers, and followed 4 billion. Please RT!", and only a few will die having "I had one dream, I made it real. I'm now in peace!"

Take some moments and uni-task and go through this <a href="http://www.slideshare.net/padday/the-real-life-social-network-v2">http://www.slideshare.net/padday/the-real-life-social-network-v2</a>

And then take some more moments and enjoy someone's dream <a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Yk_Qkz_5ti8">http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Yk_Qkz_5ti8</a> (I'm watching it while writing this)
It will give you a boost and possibly put you back on track. Or at least make you think. It does all that to me, at least :)

As always, welcome to give some good feedback below! Challenge my 2 penny!]]></content:encoded>
